Posts.Content: betmart wrote: Hi all -- I was surprised that the American Society of Clinical Oncology recommends basically only physical exams as BC follow-up, and specifically names the following as NOT recommended: CBC, liver and kidney function tests, chest X-ray, bone scan, liver ultrasound, CT scan, PET scan, tumor marker tests, and MRI. The "official" reason given is that these tests "have not been shown to lengthen the life of a person with BC" . But the guidelines (Journal of Clinical Oncology Vol 24, No. 3) are packed full of discussions of costs of medical tests, so one wonders what the real reasons are. Plus I wonder if professional liability becomes a contributing factor to the guidelines. If the tests WERE recommended and not performed, oncs may be more liable to legal consequences. I have read the responses to fd411's post "How were your mets diagnosed?" and it seemed to me that most of the responders were diagnosed through tests of some kind, not symptoms. But I'd like to ask once again here for responses -- Were you diagnosed because of symptoms or tests? Please take a moment to respond -- I am writing a magazine article about this. Thanks, Betty Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Jun 21, 2007 07:00PM betmart wrote: Hi -- A little different story. I had lymphoma in 2004 and a routine CT follow-up showed a "hot" enlarged lymph node (2 cm) in axilla. My onc ordered surgery to remove it but first said let's get a mammagram because he just didn't think it was lymphoma. Found 1 cm lump in breast, core biopsy revealed BC. Went to surgery not knowing what the lump under arm would be. Lucky (????huh?)for me, both were BC. A recurring lymphoma would have been much worse.
